 Abstract The paper analyzes the efficiency of several tax-contract systems, such as the resource rent tax, production share system, and royalty. Account is taken of their incentive effects on behavior of firms under different economic and geological conditions, with particular emphasis on areas where prospects are relatively poor. The paper shows the strengths and weaknesses of systems widely used or recommended for oil exploration and production in developing countries. An analysis of the problem of nationalization risk is also carried out, and some light shed on which of these systems is best able to cope with this problem. Though this problem has some elements of the general problem of attracting foreign investment, it is different in several important ways. For any given natural resource tract, with fixed known reserves, production at different points in time is interlinked because of the exhaustibility of the stock. Therefore, the level of production and net returns at any point in time are a substitute for those at a different point in time. A second related difference is the existence of (a3e3ent. Finally, and more importantly, before the start of exploration the amount of resource present, or even whether it exists at all is uncertain.
 - 4 - Tax-contract policy has to be decided before the existence of the resource, or its size if present is known with some degree of certainty. Formally, exploration-extraction contracts are, of course, signed before exploration begins. Tax liability is also often defined within the contract. If it is not the effect may be worse, as any possibility that tax terms may be arbitrarily changed after resource discovery has to be taken account of by the firms. The tax-contract system, under which a foreign firm agrees to exploit a natural resource tract, is effectively a Scheme for Sharing the Total Return from the project. At the time of entry, these consist of the opportunity cost of the capital that the firm will invest, the returns to the risk it will take, and the unknown rent that will accrue from the tract. The tax-contract system implicitly defines how each level of returns (positive and negative) which emerge after exploration and production are to be divided between the firm and the government. Different schemes have different effects on the firm's choice of a pattern of development and production if a resource discovery is made. That is they provide a different structure of incentives to the contracting firm. This, in turn, affects both the total returns from the project and the rents which can be obtained from it. In economic terms, therefore, the problem is to select and/or design an efficient tax-contract system for obtaining the rent element of the resource under conditions of resource uncertainty. Inherent in the process of exploration for a natural resource in a given tract is the possibility of a change in the value that the firm and government assign to the tract before and after exploration. This gives rise to the possibility that one of the parties may want to change the (explicit or implicit) terms after exploration is completed, if the penalties for so doing

More importantly the illustrative project has not only a fixed known resource amount, but also a fixed level and structure of costs and production. Such comparisons can only capture two sets of economic effects. One is changes in stopping time, or the time at which after tax revenue from declining oil flows become less than net operating costs. Thus a system like royalty which only taxes output will lower marginal revenue and advance the stopping time. This will result in more oil being left unextracted and lower total project return. The second is the effect of the tax on development of a marginal field. Thus a neutral tax will not affect the decision of whether or not to develop a marginal field. Non-neutral taxes will tend to result in nondevelopment of marginal fields, again reducing returns.  - 10 - There are two broad ways in which home countries treat host country taxes. In the deduction method, which appears to be more common, host country taxes are treated as a deduction. Home country taxes therefore apply to net income after host country taxes. Another system which is of importance is the Resource Rent Tax (RRT) a form of which has been suggested to foreign firms and host governments by the World Bank Energy department. Both the PDS and the RRT involve many different levels of Government Share/Tax rates whose perceived objective is to make the system progressive. The Royalty system is essentially like a sales tax, as it involves a tax on value of output. Though a progressive system of royalty rates, with marginal rates rising with value of output, is possible, it is not very common. The Production Share System, and its variants, is the most commonly used system in LDCs. Its essential elements are as follows. The exploration and development costs incurred before production starts are added up and carried forward. Once production starts the value of total output is divided between "Profit Oil" and "Cost Oil" according to a prespecified factor termed the "Cost Factor." Current costs as well as past costs can be reimbursed to the company from the cost oil. There is a further limitation, however, that the past costs cannot be deducted in time less than NYCT, referred to as the minimum time for cost recovery. Profit oil is in general shared under a progressive system of sharing, where the shift to higher levels of implicit taxation depends on the level of output. 2/ The Resource Rent Tax is also a fairly complicated system defined in terms of "threshold rates" of return. There are two characteristics of the resource industry, which set it apart from other industry. One is the existence of rents. If the resource amounts were known with certainty, these rents could in principle be calculated and appropriated by the resource owner by applying a 100% tax, without affecting efficiency of resource extraction. In practice, however, any feasible tax gives rise to serious incentive problems at tax values approaching 100%. The other characteristic is the uncertainty about existence of, and in the amount of the resource, when the tax contract arrangements are made. As risk taking entails a real cost to the firm, this must be accounted for in determining resource rent. The interaction of these two factors means that defining a practicable resource rent tax is not easy. R. Garnaut and Clunis Ross (1975) suggested a practical method for taxing excess profits or rents in the resource context 1/. They defined a series of "threshold rates" of return 2/. The pure profits tax is zero below the lowest threshold. As higher internal rates of return are achieved, the tax liability rises, and after each threshold is reached a different marginal tax rate is applied. The gross tax rate on higher earnings is the sum of individual marginal tax rates. This means, that the tax rate gradually approaches 100%, but never actually reaches it. These threshold rates are an attempt to deal with the two problems outlined earlier: The difficulty in determining the critical rates of return which would just draw firms into 1/ It has also been analysed by Ross (1977 a, b), Palmer (1980) and others. 2/ Termed CRATI, CRAT2, CRAT3 in the present paper.

Conclusions The significant conclusions of the study can be summarized as follows: (1) The historically popular Royalty or Severance Tax, was confirmed as the most inefficient system for extracting rents from a natural resource. Such a system has sometimes been justified on the grounds that developing country governments may have a higher discount rate than that of the firm's (They want the revenue flows to start quickly). It was found that under these circumstances the Royalty system deteriorates even further relative to others. (2) A simple income tax, commonly used for other production activities as well as in some mineral producing countries, though not the best system, is a reasonably efficient system. For this purpose the tax rate has of course to be set at the value appropriate to the geologic prospects and economic conditions.
 - 99 - (3) A Production Share System of the India-Indonesia type simplified to have only one sharing level, instead of the multiple levels commonly found in these systems, performed marginally worse than the simple income tax. With multiple levels, however, the efficiency of this systems drops drastically, becoming worse than with a single Royalty level (but not a variable royalty rate system). (4) A carefully specified Resource Rent Tax System was found to be the most efficient system. Care had to be exercised in not setting the highest applicable cumulation rate too high relative to the discount rate. The highest (reasonably) efficient cumulation rate also depended on the host government income tax, and was positively related to it. For example, with no income taxes, a cumulation rate of 10% relative to a discount rate of 6%, the resource rent tax system becomes the most inefficient system. With a host government income tax rate of 15-30% it is, however, almost as efficient. (5) Interestingly, the Resource Rent Tax System was also the most progressive system. In fact the other systems mentioned above were all regressive, in that the correlation between the host government's share and the project's present value was negative. (6) Multiple levels of Resource Rent Taxation which have been explicitly designed to, increase the progressivity of this system do not have any such effect in the absence of an income tax. An appropriately defined single level Resource Rent tax was able to replicate the
 - 100 - progressivity level of a multi-level system. In the presence of a home income tax, however, multiple levels could be used to improve progressivity. (7) Variation of the cumulation rate for the Resource Rent Tax system showed the existence of a trade-off between efficiency and progressivity. Efficiency was negatively, and progressivity was positively related to the cumulation rate. The trade-off was characterized by two well defined segments. In the initial segment, as the cumulation rate is raised above the firm discount rate, progressivity rises rapidly with only small losses in efficiency. In the second segment, lying beyond a critical cumulation rate, the position is reversed, with efficiency falling rapidly with little gain in progressivity. (8) Separate theoretical analysis had suggested that Sovereign/Nationalization Risk could be mitigated by a system in which the Host Government's Share rose with the value (or size) of the reserve discovery for very high value fields. Though progressive Resource Rent tax systems were the only ones to have this characteristic, it was not enough to reduce Nationalisation risk by a significant factor. The reason is that substantial amounts of progression occur for small reserve sizes lying well below the mean reserve.
 - 101 - (9) Like the multi-level production share systems, systems like Variable Profit Share and Variable Royalty, which have continuously varying taxes, are also very inefficient. Their efficiency is often worse than that of the two level production share system. A more definite conclusion is not possible because the precise degree of rate progression is very important. These systems are also regressive. (10) Except for the resource rent tax systems with cumulation rates greater than the firm discount rate, efficiency and progressivity are generally positively related. It is therefore generally sufficient to look only at their efficiency properties. (11) A recent version of the British Petroleum Revenue Tax which allows firms not to pay any tax on a specified volume of initial production, was found to be less efficient than a Royalty. When the allowed volume is reduced to zero the system improves considerably. As it stands however, this system will extract competitive rents only when the probability of discovery is very low. With better prospects all additional revenues go to the firms. (12) The use, by the home government, of a Credit instead of a Deduction system of foreign source income taxation, made no difference in the efficiency ranking of different systems. As expected, much more of the resource rent is captured by the host government under the Credit than under the Deduction system. Under the credit system, the host government should use an effective income tax rate equal to
 - 102 - that of the home government so as to capture the maximum amount of rent. This should be combined with an RRT system with a reasonably high cumulation rate to maintain efficiency. For example, with an effective home income tax rate of 45% an equal effective host income tax can be combined with an RRT system having a cumulation rate up to 2.5 times the firm discount rate.

 - 104 - Section A.1: Introduction The objective of this brief paper is to explore the problem of Sovereign risk in natural resource contracts between host governments and foreign firms. In virtually all developed countries, the political-legal framework based on a strong belief in private property rights, provides a stable tax and contract environment, for both foreign and domestic firms. Leland(1979) has analyzed optimal risk sharing between government and firms in such an environment. In many developing countries (LDCs) the belief in private property rights, especially those of foreign firms, is far from absolute. This gives rise to the problem of sovereign risk, which can take two forms: The explicit modification of contract terms, as for example through nationalization; An implicit change such as through the imposition of new taxes on selected sub-sets of firms, as for example an excess profits tax. Foreign firms conceive of sovereign risk primarily as political risk. This can take the form of a build up of public and political pressure which forces a government to change its earlier intentions or in extreme case the replacement of the existing government by a more radical one. In other words, even if the existing government has no intention of changing contract terms, the foreign firm conceives the possibility of changes in socio- political environment which would result in such contract changes. In the natural resource context there is of course the special problem that the value of the tract of land which is the subject of the contract, is unknown at the time the contract is signed and becomes known only after an expenditure of resources. This gives rise to a pecuLiar dichotomy in socio-political perception which is an important factor in the political risk: Ex-post
 - 105 - (exploration), the greater the size and value of the natural resource discovery, the stronger the perception that there was little ex-ante risk, and therefore the more unjustified any returns for risk taking. In other words the political risk is positively related to the value of the resource discovered, or more specifically to the net return to the firm. Eaton and Gersovitz have recently analyzed the problem of a sovereign (country) borrower, who willfully defaults under certain circumstances. The present note will, however, assume that a host government has no intention, at the time it signs the contract, of changing contract terms later. The foreign firm perceives a risk of change of contract terms, however, and the host government must take account of this perception in devising contract terms.!'  - 127 - RESOURCE RENT TAX In the RRT system the tax base is calculated by cumulating expenditures and revenues at a specific interest rate. Each year an annual cash flow is figured: cash flow = gross revenue - operating cost - royalty payments - exploration expenses - development expense. In the intital years of exploration and development, the annual cash flows are negative. When production revenues start to come in the annual flows become positive, and at some point the accumulated value of the flows becomes positive. At this point (zero cash flow point) and beyond the tax is imposed. The model is structured to allow for three different rates of accumulation. The cumulation with the lowest rate will reach the zero cash flow point soonest and the tax will be levied first at the associated rate. The other cumulations occur simultaneously at successively higher rates. In addition to the normal cumulation of costs and revenues at these higher rates, any previous RRT payments that the firm makes are subtracted from the iccumulation. The combination of a higher accumulation rate and the deduction if prior RRT payments will delay the imposition of the tax at the second and third levels. An effective tax rate can be calculated using the following formula: effective rate - RRTRI + RRTR2(1-RRTR1) + RRTR3[1-RRTR1-RRTR2(1-RRTR1)] (RRTR1,2,3 are the three tax rates) For example, if RRT rates of .25, .50 and .75 were all being levied, the effective rate would be: .25 + .50(1-.25) + .75(1-.25-.50(1-.25)) - .25 + .375 + .281 - .906 The RRT does not qualify for the U.S. foreign income tax credit.

Fixed Royalty RPFS = RLAMV * GRREV Royalty payment = tax rate * gross revenue No deductions are permitted before applying the tax. Variable Royalty The rate variation can be either production or revenue based. Four inputs are needed: ROYRT = initial or minimum royalty rate RRTMAX - maximum royalty rate ROYFAC - factor which changes royalty rate based on annual production or revenue PRODF - threshold level of production (or revenue) below which royalty rate remains unchanged at the minimum For the production based system, the rate is calculated as follows: PRODU = (Total annual production - PRODF)/1,000,000 the new rate: RLAMV - ROYRT + ROYFAC * PRODU For the revenue based system, the steps are: PRODU - (Gross Revenue - PRODF)/1,000,000 the new rate: RLAMV ROYRT + ROYFAC * PRODU Each time the program checks that the new rate does not exceed the maximum, RRTMAX. doc.abstracts: The paper analyzes the efficiency of several tax-contract systems, such as the resource rent tax, production share system, and royalty. Account is taken of their incentive effects on behaviour of firms under different economic and geological conditions, with particular emphasis on areas where prospects are relatively poor. The paper shows the strengths and weaknesses of systems widely used or recommended for oil exploration and production in developing countries. An analysis of the problem of nationalization risk is also carried out, and some light shed on which of the these systems is best able to cope with this problem.
